Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Department of Oceanography in the College of Geosciences at Texas A&M University (TAMU) is recruiting academically talented graduate students with demonstrated financial need to become Oceanography Scholars. Scholarships will be awarded to a total of 22 new students admitted in three cohorts; the first two will be composed of five M.S. and four Ph.D. students each, while the third will contain five M.S. students. Oceanography Scholars receive additional support from faculty research mentors and formal training in teaching pedagogies through courses and workshops offered by the university's Center for Teaching Excellence, Graduate Teaching Academy and the Department of Oceanography.

This program is designed to educate scientists with interdisciplinary expertise in oceanographic processes to solve environmental, social and economically important challenges facing the nation by conducting research in their field. Doctoral graduates will enter the workforce directly from the program while M.S. graduates may either enter the workforce or matriculate into Ph.D. programs where they will build new knowledge to address scientific challenges that are relevant to both human and environmental sustainability. Through targeted recruiting efforts, academically talented students with financial need will matriculate at TAMU, conduct research, and graduate prepared to address areas of high national need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Oceanography Scholars STEM Achievements at TAMU

The Department of Oceanography at Texas A&M University has hosted a program for Scholars of Oceanography funded by the S-STEM program at NSF starting with a cohort of 10 students entering in 2014 and supporting a total of 40 students by 2021. Collectively they amassed the following achievements:

Summary of S-STEM Scholar Achievements

  • 40 students received scholarships that covered part of their tuition, fees, stipend and insurance. Many received travel grants for presenting at national meetings.
  • 769 days at sea collecting data for theses and dissertations.
  • 177 days doing non-ship field work collecting data for theses and dissertations.
  • 52 presentations at professional meetings plus numerous student presentations at our S-STEM seminars.
  • 20 published papers with S-STEM Scholars as authors or co-authors
  • 21 S-STEM scholars have graduated, with others finishing soon. Ten of the students entered the program in the last two years.

Oceanography is a multidisciplinary field where a strong disciplinary background in a physical or biological science is broadened at the graduate level for students to be able to assess complex, multidisciplinary environments. Research on marine processes is an area of increasing social, scientific, and national security importance due to human activities and natural environmental processes and disasters (tsunamis, oil spills, ocean acidification, harmful algal blooms, climate disruption, sea level rise, etc.) that affect oceans from the coastal region to the deep sea. This includes strategically important and unexplored areas of the Arctic Ocean as summer ice shrinks, allowing navigation, exploration, and exploitation and, therefore, potential territorial disputes. The U.S. is increasingly seeking marine economic resources, such as oil, gas, essential minerals/elements, seafood and pharmaceuticals, thus making the sea environmentally, socially, economically, and strategically important.

Our students have participated in important projects. Several students were involved in rapid response projects in Galveston Bay and the Gulf of Mexico after record-breaking flooding caused by Hurricane Harvey in 2017. Some students were involved on expeditions investigating the impact of the Deep-Water Horizon oil blowout in the Gulf of Mexico. That involvement provided an education about regulatory policy and pollution remediation. Other students have been involved with detection of Harmful Algal Blooms in the Gulf of Mexico, providing a different opportunity to combine science with regulatory policy on shell fisheries and water quality. Some S-STEM scholars were involved with ongoing studies of hypoxia (harmfully low oxygen concentrations in continental shelf bottom waters) in the Gulf of Mexico near the Mississippi outflow. Understanding the causes of hypoxia helps to understand how to mitigate this condition that threatens stationary seafloor animals. Some S-STEM scholars studied the impacts of ocean acidification, a global threat that needs further research on remediation because it affects many types of fisheries.

Our scholars have been on expeditions in the Gulf of Mexico, Galapagos Islands, Palau, Hawaii, North Pacific, Atlantic Ocean, Southern Ocean between both South Africa and South America and Antarctica, and the Arctic Ocean, thus increasing their international exposure and cultural awareness. 

Our students spent a total of 769 days at sea with an additional 177 days of non-ship field work and many months in their labs. Prior to and during these oceanographic expeditions students learned sampling and analysis techniques from their faculty mentors and from other students, giving them hands-on experience in studying the big issues listed earlier. These expeditions are incredibly high-impact experiences for students because they meet and interact with other students and outstanding scientists ? fantastic opportunities for professional networking on many levels.

We had 1-3 S-STEM lunches for all S-STEM Scholars each fall and spring semester. This was very helpful in mentoring the new S-STEM students. S-STEM Scholars made short presentations of their research work ? at whatever stage they were in their work. These presentations were often practice opportunities for presentations at regional and national meetings. We were impressed with the engagement and willingness of students to provide constructive feedback to fellow students on how to better present their findings. These lunch seminars also provided a forum in which we could introduce new students and faculty/staff, remind students of any activities and address any questions/concerns they had.

The graduate students in the Oceanography Department have a student-run organization - the Oceanography Graduate Council (OGC). OGC has student-elected officers and organizes activities in the fall to welcome new graduate students, including prospective S-STEM students. Participation in OGC helped to integrate the S-STEM Scholars with all other students in the department. The quality of our S-STEM students is demonstrated by the fact that the top four positions in that organization (Pres., VP, Sec., Treas.) have often been held by S-STEM Scholars. These opportunities developed leadership skills with students who will be their lifetime colleagues. As a result, our program has graduated well-educated, skilled scientists in technical areas of national need.
